4564: Alabaster Dragon.author: tcollins
4564: Alabaster Dragon.text_parsed:
The mileage you'll get out of this card really depends on the deck you run it with...the less graveyard recursion you have, the better this card fits. It has absolutely no place in a reanimation deck (obviously) whereas in a pure {W} deck it shuffles itself back into the library to be drawn again, it's not the best ability tacked onto a 4/4 flyer for {4}{W}{W}, but in games that get very long and drawn out, the ability can really matter.

Also, I like the artwork.

4566: Angelic Renewal.author: Mode
4566: Angelic Renewal.text_parsed:
Pretty awesome with creatures who have an Evoke cost as well, since they will be sacrificed and then returned thanks to the Renewal, not only allowing to get them onto the battlefield pretty cheap but also triggering their cip/etb trigger twice!
Mulldrifter for instance will provide a 2/2 flying body and four cards for .
Nevermaker and Æthersnipe will bounce cards.
Four four mana you get 7/7 bodies from Walker of the Grove (which either gives a further and up to a second 4/4 body) or Cloudthresher (which has flash, reach and deals and 4 damage to each creature and each player).
At instant speed Briarhorn provides +3/+3 twice and a 3/3 body for ,
or Dawnfluke for can prevent 3 damage to any target twice and provides a 0/3 body. There are lots of great choices.

This card also does a good job with Persist creatures, allowing them to get to the battlefield two more times. (You might use Saffi Eriksdotter for that manner as well)

It also does a somewhat useful job with Spirits who have Soulshift.
4566: Angelic Renewal.text_posted:
Pretty awesome with creatures who have an [u]Evoke[/u] cost as well, since they will be sacrificed and then returned thanks to the Renewal, not only allowing to get them onto the battlefield pretty cheap but also triggering their cip/etb trigger [i]twice[/i]!
[autocard]Mulldrifter[/autocard] for instance will provide a 2/2 flying body and four cards for [2U].
[autocard]Nevermaker[/autocard] and [autocard]Æthersnipe[/autocard] will bounce cards. 
Four four mana you get 7/7 bodies from [autocard]Walker of the Grove[/autocard] (which either gives a further and up to a second 4/4 body) or [autocard]Cloudthresher[/autocard] (which has flash, reach and deals and 4 damage to each creature and each player).
At instant speed [autocard]Briarhorn[/autocard] provides +3/+3 twice and a 3/3 body for [1G],
or [autocard]Dawnfluke[/autocard] for [W] can prevent 3 damage to any target twice and provides a 0/3 body. There are lots of great choices.

This card also does a good job with [u]Persist[/u] creatures, allowing them to get to the battlefield two more times. (You might use [autocard]Saffi Eriksdotter[/autocard] for that manner as well)

It also does a somewhat useful job with Spirits who have [u]Soulshift[/u].

Sure, it doesn't have the versatility or card advantage of shelter or the reach of brave the elements, and it cant protect your dudes from oblivion rings and pacifisms, but it does have some very interesting interactions that can't be found with 'strictly better' cards.

My personal favorite interaction is with karmic guide, and it fits the flavor perfectly. Another great angelic renewal target is the sun titan, as it provides protection for such a huge target and the resurrected creature means you dont lose card advantage.

4573: Debt of Loyalty.author: Ragamander
4573: Debt of Loyalty.text_parsed:
This card is a direct chronological sequel to Desperate Gambit, which depicts Starke of Rath charging into the battle between Maraxus of Keld and Gerrard Capashen, the outcome of which we see here. Neato!

Oh, also, Debt of Loyalty is a really cool card. Save a creature from death, and it pledges its allegiance to you. You can use it to save your own threat or to steal your opponent's if it's going to die. Surprise! I'll be taking that!

Works well with Beast Within, because regeneration and the control swap will replace the destruction, causing you to become its controller by the time Beast Within checks for it (so YOU get the 3/3 Beast token). Best of all, this means you retain control of Starke of Rath if you cast Debt of Loyalty on his target!

Wait a minute...how does that flavor make sense?

4582: Master of Arms.author: Saikuba
4582: Master of Arms.text_parsed:
When this was printed combat worked so that tapped creatures didn't deal damage, so the ability was a sneaky way of protecting the card while attacking. Then the rules changed in sixth edition and the card became pointless. The Wizards decided to make the card prevent the damage of the creatures it tapped again because that was the whole point of the card (much like how Howling Mine and similar cards were errattaed to only work while untapped). Then they decided to get rid of the damage prevention again.

So I guess in two years Master of Arms will be able to prevent the damage of the creatures that he taps again.

4582: Master of Arms.author: Mode
4582: Master of Arms.text_parsed:
It might be intuitively more straight-forward if the Oracle is identical with the card text for new players, so I can see why they decided to keep the card nerfed by the 6th Edition Rule Changes.
Additionally it could be argued that M10 Rule Changes nerfed lots and lots of creatures like Mogg Fanatic as well, and these cards didn't get an errata either to even things out.

However, I think there are far less cards specifically desinged to made use of the tapped-blocker than there were cards designed to make use of combat damage using the stack.

Adding the original intention of this card, the damage prevention, would be easier to do and get far less messy than trying to fix Mogg Fanaticesque cards.
If they simply add a note dedicated to this wording which explains why the Oracle seemingly does more than what the card did, things will be cleared up and players even learn something about Magic's history as well.

Still I think I'm fine with either wording, both has its pros and cons.

4583: Mistmoon Griffin.author: BegleOne
4583: Mistmoon Griffin.text_parsed:
This thing can be used to reanimate anything; it has the same converted mana cost as Breath of Life, and as far as white reanimation goes that's about as good as it is going to get.

It's useful. You can use spellshapers or tireless tribe to get the big stuff (Iona, Blazing Archon) into your graveyard. The biggest problem with it in mono-white is trying to stack your graveyard and just trying to draw the right big stuff to reanimate, but it can be done. If you splash blue you have a lot more ability to draw and discard when you need to, and you can aim for Jin-Gitaxias as your reanimation target.

Not a viable legacy strategy, but this guy could be a quality component of a fun tier 2 or 3 deck if you play around with it. It's a lot of fun to have a bunch of equipment on him and be swinging for lots every turn, and your opponents doesn't want to kill it because something even nastier is in the graveyard waiting to come out.

4583: Mistmoon Griffin.author: ChumleyX
4583: Mistmoon Griffin.text_parsed:
@mrredhatter: I have to respectfully disagree. Mistmoon Griffin is a far better choice than Mtenda Griffin in a griffin tribal for a variety of reasons.

First, Mistmoon puts the creature directly into play, effectively replacing himself and keeping your creature count the same. In contrast, Mtenda puts himself and target dead griffin into your hand. So you'd need to recast both, tying up your time and resources. Additionally, Mtenda's ability is only playable during your upkeep (a major disadvantage of the card), keeping you down 1 mana for the turn.

Second, while Mistmoon only works with your top creature card, that card doesn't have to be a griffin. So tribal support cards like Griffin Rider will work just fine with him, but would not work with Mtenda.

4585: Revered Unicorn.author: Yukikah
4585: Revered Unicorn.text_parsed:
I suppose the 2/3 body for 2CMC is good enough to give this something, but the ability seems like a negative to me rather than a positive. I mean, you bring this put turn two and...

Turn 3: pay 1
Turn 4: pay 2
Turn 5: pay 3
Turn 6: pay 4

Then let's say it dies turn 7. Washing out the actual casting cost as paying for the body, at this point you've payed 10 mana for 5 life. I mean, Angel's Mercy is rated ONE star and it's 4 mana for 7 life. So I don't think I'm too far off base saying that this is basically just a 2/3 with cumulative upkeep; the life gain is pretty much negligable.

4589: Southern Paladin.author: Ferlord
4589: Southern Paladin.text_parsed:
"IIiiiinnn South Dominaria, I was born and raised,
by the palm trees, where I would spend most of my days.

Shining my axe to a awesome gold shine,
Killin' some Goblins to pass by the time.

Well, the East and the West, they're bad to the bone!
Started killing my pals in my allies zone!

I asked if I could be played to avenge my friends,
They said, "You're not that good! Your mana curve is hard to ascend!"

I begged and moaned, and said my chance was near,
But they replied, "We'll just reprint you in a later year."

I waited and waited, and 4 years came around,
BUt I was replaced by some bloke with a frown!

This, ends, The tale of the South, well that's just sad,
But, in hindsight, I am very, very glad!
I don't ever need to open my mouth!
'cause I'll always be the Master of the God-Damned South!

4591: Volunteer Reserves.author: jeff-heikkinen
4591: Volunteer Reserves.text_parsed:
Ah, Weatherlight. The last gasp for both Banding and (until Coldsnap) Cumulative Upkeep. It seems like the design team were trying their best to make the case for keeping both mechanics, exploring previously unused avenues for making CU interesting and pushing Banding onto somewhat stronger cards than had ever been the case before.

Obviously this is no Constructed card, so let's talk Limited. 4 toughness on a creature with Banding makes for an almost impenetrable defensive line, or can nearly guarantee the survival of one selected attacker if you prefer. Basically this guy usually creates a stalemate (or sometimes a slight advantage) for you on the ground, buying you time to draw whatever you need to break said stalemate, while slowly chewing up the mana you need to play whatever that is. Which is fine; when you're ready to make your move, you can just pile him into a band, let him die a heroic death, and still probably end up better off for whatever he manages to take with him.

Pretty good, Limited-wise - but not, by itself, a convincing case for keeping either of its keywords in the game.

This is also a HUGE target when it comes into play because if it's destroyed you lose 3 cards for your opponent's 1 card.  Even a Boomerang will be painful since you still lost 2 lands.  There are MUCH better ways of getting any color mana nowadays.  They could have made this card so that it didn't have such a huge downside.  Maybe sacrifice 1 untapped land and have it produce only 2 mana instead.

Replacement effects are static effects and don't use the stack. If you don't sacrifice the lands, you never even get to the point where you're *trying* to put it into play. Your attempt is replaced with "put Lotus Vale in your graveyard." There's no card in the game that stifles a replacement effect. If you really want a brainteaser, consider: what happens when you use the static replacement effect of Vesuva naming Lotus Vale?

Okay! So I thought of an infinite mana any color combo with this card, Oboro Breezecaller, Patron of the Moon, and two other lands on the field that don't bounce other land.

Step 1: Tap Lotsu Vale for three {W} {U} {B} {R} {G}.
Step 2: Pay {2} to bounce misc. land with Oboro Breezecaller's ability. Untap Lotus Vale. One floating mana of the color tapped with Lotus Vale.
Step 3: Repeat Step 1 than 2. Two mana floating of any color.
Step 4: Pay {1} to place the two land you bounced into play with Patron of the Moon's ability. One mana of any color you choose left floating.
Step 5: Repeat Steps 1 through 4 for infinite mana of any color combination!

Yay! I think I semi-redeemed Oboro Breezecaller, with it's absolutely GORGEOUS artwork!

Sorry for any formatting issues, and I'm sure someone else has though of this before, but I didn't see it posted up here so... And I know it's fragile, but hey! Who's gonna suspect Oboro Breezecaller as part of an infinite mana combo?

4595: Winding Canyons.author: Pantheon
4595: Winding Canyons.text_parsed:
I had Winding Canyons in play in a very long game, my opponent was playing a nasty blue control deck. He had Arcane Laboratory in play and a ton of counterspells in his deck. I had Emrakul, The Aeons Torn in my had for the longest time. He cast a creature on his turn and BAM! I tapped 17 mana (thank you Sol Ring, Worn Powerstone, Thran Dynamo and Urzatron lands) to get Emrakul out at the end of his turn. It was beautiful, I was able to attack with Emrakul twice.

EDIT: @KKgourmet, D'oh! Spaced out on that, of course it is!
